answers: A man convicted four years ago in the oldest cold case ever tried was freed Friday after an Illinois judge vacated his conviction and subsequent life sentence, CNN reports. The case was reopened in 2008, and McCullough was arrested in 2011 and convicted the following year. After an appeal by McCullough, Illinois state's attorney Richard Schmack launched a six-month investigation that found what he calls "clear and convincing evidence" that McCullough is innocent. While the judge Friday vacated McCullough's conviction, he stopped short of declaring him innocent, and a new trial will be held, the Chicago Tribune reports. McCullough, who lived in the same neighborhood as the kidnapped girl, says he was 40 miles away at an Air Force recruiting center at the time of the kidnapping. It's an alibi that passed a polygraph test in 1957 and made it impossible for him to be the culprit based on the FBI's original timeline for the kidnapping. That timeline was later changed by police, and Schmack says documents—including phone and Air Force records—supporting McCullough's alibi were wrongly not allowed at his trial. A friend of the kidnapped girl picked McCullough out of a photo lineup when the case was reopened. But his was the only non-yearbook photo in the lineup, and she picked a different man out of a photo lineup 50 years earlier. That info wasn't allowed at McCullough's trial either. No physical evidence was ever found to support McCullough's conviction.

Two recent studies, published in the journal Infection and Immunity, reveal the harmful effects of cigarette smoke on antibiotic-resistant bacteria, particularly Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). The research, led by Dr. Laura E. Crotty Alexander at the University of California, San Diego, shows that exposure to cigarette smoke increases the virulence and resistance of MRSA.

In the first study, Crotty Alexander and her team found that MRSA bacteria exposed to cigarette smoke extract were more resistant to the immune cells' defenses, such as reactive oxygen species and antimicrobial peptides. The bacteria's cell walls were altered, making it harder for the immune system to eliminate them. This resistance persisted for 24 hours after exposure, suggesting it could be inherited. When these smoke-exposed MRSA were introduced to mice, they caused significantly higher mortality and were more efficient at invading human cells in lab cultures.

A similar study, led by Dr. Crotty Alexander and published earlier, investigated the effects of e-cigarette vapor on MRSA resistance. It showed that while e-cigarette smoke also altered the bacteria's cell walls, the effect was less pronounced compared to cigarette smoke. The researchers concluded that both cigarette smoke and e-cigarette vapor contribute to the increased resistance of MRSA, potentially making infections more difficult to treat.

These findings highlight the dual role of cigarette smoke in harming both smokers and promoting the growth of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. They emphasize the need for further research to understand the implications of this resistance and to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of smoking on public health, especially in healthcare settings where MRSA is commonly encountered.
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

2. Passage 2 discusses the Internet Archive's efforts to preserve web pages by archiving them as they are created and fixing broken links. answers: Using methods borrowed from Google, a group of researchers has analyzed all Wikipedia pages and determined that, at least on the English language version of the site, Frank Sinatra is the world's most important person. Second place goes to Michael Jackson, and third to Pope Pius XII. When factoring in all 24 language editions of the online encyclopedia, the team found that Adolf Hitler ranked the most important person, while Michael Jackson was again second and Madonna third, reports the Guardian. "Our analysis shows that most important historical figures across Wikipedia language editions are born in western countries after the 17th century, and are male," the authors write. The researchers combined two algorithms to reach these conclusions. First, Google's PageRank algorithm, which determines a page's importance based on how many other pages link to it. In using PageRank on Wikipedia, the most important person in the world was 18th-century Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus, likely because the pages of organism after organism link back to the "father of taxonomy." So the researchers added an algorithm called CheiRank, which determines importance based on the number of outgoing links, the thought being that an important person would himself be connected to other important people, things, and events. Using the two together—an approach they dubbed 2DRank—no one beat out Frank Sinatra on English pages or Adolf Hitler across all language versions. The news articles cover various scientific discoveries and insights into the evolution of humans and their tool-making abilities. Here's a summary:

1. A study published in Science suggests that dramatic climate changes in East Africa around 320,000 years ago may have driven the development of toolmaking advancements and trading networks among Homo sapiens or their relatives. The discovery of new Middle Stone Age tools and red pigment in Olorgesailie Basin, Kenya, indicates a shift in foraging behavior and the potential for long-distance communication through the use of obsidian, a rare material found far away.

2. Researchers have uncovered the oldest known Middle Stone Age tools, dating back to around 320,000 years ago. These tools, including spearpoints and smaller implements, show a gradual downsizing trend, possibly indicating increased mobility and adaptation to changing environments. However, the exact origin of these tools (Homo sapiens or a closely related species) is uncertain due to the lack of fossil evidence.

3. The Olorgesailie region's tools, made from obsidian, suggest the existence of trading networks among dispersed human populations. This implies that H. sapiens or their ancestors were able to cope with environmental stress by partnering with neighboring communities and innovating their tool-making techniques.

4. The shift from the Acheulian culture to the Middle Stone Age in Olorgesailie is marked by the appearance of smaller, specialized tools, which indicate advanced thinking and planning. These tools were made with fine-grained materials and were likely used for specific purposes, such as hunting and possibly symbolic purposes.

5. The new findings challenge the traditional view that modern behaviors emerged only after humans migrated out of Africa. Archaeologists now believe that some aspects of "human revolution" occurred much earlier, around 300,000 years ago, in response to environmental changes in the region.

6. The Olorgesailie discoveries suggest that one or more hominin groups were engaging in seemingly "modern" activities, involving the transportation of exotic materials and the transmission of technological skills. This implies the existence of expanded social networks and the potential for cultural and cognitive evolution before the emergence of Homo sapiens.

In summary, these findings challenge the conventional timeline of human evolution, revealing that the development of modern behaviors and tool-making capabilities occurred earlier than previously thought, possibly in response to environmental pressures in East Africa. The existence of trading networks and technological innovation among early humans highlights the adaptability and complexity of our ancestors.
answers: For decades, the human story was one told through signs of modernity—art, tools, burials—found only after Homo sapiens left Africa. Recent discoveries pushing back the date of departure are helping to change that narrative, as are three new studies in Science. Together, they describe the earliest stone tools of their kind in East Africa as well as the earliest evidence for long-distance transport of raw materials in the region, per Science News. Researchers previously believed the Early Stone Age marked by large, primitive tools (hand axes and cleavers) made way for the Middle Stone Age and its smaller tools (spearpoints and blades) around 280,000 years ago. But stone tools found in Kenya's Olorgesailie Basin show hominin groups—it's not clear which species is responsible—had developed these more advanced tools approximately 320,000 years ago. "We see a smaller technology, a more diverse series of stone tools … designed for specific purposes," researcher Rick Potts tells NPR. An expert not involved in the study says the tools are so "prepared and retouched" they suggest the Middle Stone Age likely started even earlier. What drove it? Microscopic and chemical analyses of the region's soil show the landscape was rapidly shifting between wet and dry conditions, meaning hominins might have been forced to adapt. But as the technology also coincides with the emergence of Homo sapiens in Africa, it's possible that the human mind deserves credit. The tools themselves suggest the development of trading networks, too. Some were made of rocks carried from 55 miles away, says Potts. Others were made of obsidian from as far as 30 miles away, per the Conversation. (These stone tools are also making waves.)

Statistical methods, particularly Bayesian inference, have been used in various search operations, including the hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 and the location of the missing Air France Flight 447. Bayesian techniques allow experts to update probability estimates based on new information, such as flight paths, weather patterns, and search coverage. In the case of Flight 370, the focus shifted from an accident to a deliberate diversion, which influenced the probability of finding the plane in specific locations.

Bayesian inference formalizes common sense by assigning probabilities to situations, allowing for adjustments based on new evidence. For instance, in the Air France search, the team calculated probabilities for beacon detection, beacon damage, and the movement of debris, combining these factors to narrow down the search area.

The challenge in the Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 search is the additional complexity due to the new evidence, which complicates the Bayesian calculations. However, Bayesian methods can adapt to changing information, as long as the searchers initially consider the possibility of the plane not being in the initial search area.

While Bayesian statistics have proven useful in these searches, not all airlines or governments use them, and the success of the current Malaysian search for Flight 370 remains uncertain. The discovery of debris from the Air France crash, however, demonstrates the potential power of Bayesian methods in resolving mysteries at sea.

In summary, Bayesian statistics have played a significant role in enhancing search operations, particularly in cases where traditional methods have been insufficient, and their adaptability to new information is a key advantage. However, the ultimate fate of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, despite the search efforts, remains uncertain.
answers: Forget satellite images and aerial searches—the best way to find Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may be with mathematical techniques dating back to the 18th century, the BBC reports. That's how Air France flight 447 was found in 2009, using "Bayesian statistics" to measure the probability of the plane being in one place or another. Named after Presbyterian minister and mathematician Thomas Bayes, the technique allowed experts to apply several factors to each point on a map: For example, what was the chance it crashed from mechanical failure? How far do planes tend to crash from their last known location? What was the chance that search teams missed debris in various locations? It's like picking a restaurant by balancing how full it is, what your favorite restaurant-review website says, and so on—except that experts hunting for Airbus A330 did that for each point where plane may have crashed in the Atlantic, Five Thirty-Eight notes. It was so hard that the US team of statisticians invited by France gave up, until they de-emphasized one statistic: that a plane's black box emits a signal after a crash 90% of the time. They changed their findings, and presto, the plane was found. Bayesian techniques have helped people find World War II U-boats, men overboard, and sunken treasure, but there's no evidence that Malaysia is employing them now. "I suspect that they just guess, like professional baseball managers used to do before Moneyball," says a biostatistician.

On January 31, 2018, a rare celestial event occurred with a total lunar eclipse, known as a "Super Blue Moon," visible from parts of Australia, the western United States, and other regions. The Virtual Telescope Project, in collaboration with several professional astro-photographers, offered an online, free virtual eclipse session for viewers to witness the stunning beauty of the event. The eclipse was a combination of a Supermoon (occurring during a full moon when the moon is at its closest to Earth) and a Blue Moon (the second full moon in a month), making it a unique spectacle.

The team consisted of experienced astronomers and photographers, including Dean Hooper from Melbourne, John Stevenson from Canberra, Chris Stockdale from Latrobe Valley Astronomical Society, and others from various locations. The Virtual Telescope Project also utilized the "Pearl" telescope at Tenagra Observatories for the event.

In addition to the live eclipse session, the project showcased the Supermoon rising above Rome, creating excitement worldwide. The online event started at 11:30 UT, and a Supermoon rising above Rome's landmarks was broadcast later that day at 16:00 UT.

The total phase of the eclipse lasted for 77 minutes, with the moon's lower limb appearing brighter due to the Earth's shadow. This type of eclipse, often referred to as a "blood moon," is considered unusual, with the last one occurring nearly 152 years ago.

The next total Blue Moon eclipse is expected on December 31, 2028, and January 31, 2037. Supermoons, which appear 14% larger and 30% brighter, are not uncommon, but having three in a row is indeed exceptional. The January 31 event was particularly noteworthy due to the eclipse and its visibility across different regions.

Astronomy enthusiasts could enjoy the supermoon and lunar eclipse without leaving their homes by watching the Virtual Telescope's livestreams. For those who wanted to capture the event, tips were provided on how to photograph the moon, such as using the moon on the screen to lock focus and adjusting exposure settings.

It's important to note that the supermoon and lunar eclipse were safe to view without any special equipment, unlike solar eclipses, which require protective glasses.
answers: Look up at the sky on Jan. 31 and you may witness a sight unseen for 150 years. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)
